title: How to Clean a Metal Backsplash

steps.headline: Find the direction of the metal’s grain.
steps.description: Look closely at the metal backsplash. The metal particles may appear to move in a certain direction, such as side to side. If your backsplash has a noticeable grain, always scrub in the direction of it. This will prevent the metal from taking on tiny scratches.

steps.headline: Dampen a microfiber cloth in warm water.
steps.description: Use a microfiber cloth or non-abrasive sponge. Metal brushes and scrub pads will scratch your backsplash, so avoid them. Warm water cleaning, when done routinely, limits the need for deeper cleaning. Never use hot water on the backsplash. A mild detergent, such as a dish soap like Dawn or a non-chloride cleanser, can also be used for extra cleaning strength. Add a drop or two of the detergent to the water.

steps.headline: Wipe off the stains with the cloth.
steps.description: Use the microfiber cloth to clean the backsplash. Work in circular motions along the grain. Most of the time, the day’s stains will come right off. Older stains are likely to require deeper cleaning. Never use scrub pads or wire brushes on the backsplash. These will scratch it.

steps.headline: Dry the backsplash with a clean cloth.
steps.description: Get a dry cloth and use it to absorb the water on the metal. Although metal backsplashes are resistant to damage, hard water can weaken them. It’s better to dry the metal by hand so water doesn’t sit on it.

steps.headline: Combine baking soda and warm water in a bowl.
steps.description: Mix a cup (240 mL) of baking soda in a cup of warm water. Stir them together to form a paste.

steps.headline: Let the baking soda paste dry on the stain.
steps.description: Apply the paste to the stain using your cloth or sponge. Wait for the paste to dry. Take a clean, dry cloth and use it to wipe off the paste. Check to see if the stain has been removed.

steps.headline: Combine vinegar and water in a spray bottle.
steps.description: Mix an equal amount of vinegar and warm water. Add them to a spray bottle if possible, since this will allow you to coat the stain with an even, controlled amount of the mixture.

steps.headline: Let the vinegar mixture sit on the stain for five minutes.
steps.description: Spray the mixture onto the stain. After five minutes, come back and prepare to finish treating the backsplash with a general wash..

steps.headline: Wipe off the vinegar with a damp cloth.
steps.description: Dampen a soft cloth in warm water. Rub the cloth against the metal’s grain over the stained areas. Make sure all vinegar is removed.

steps.headline: Dry the backsplash with a clean cloth.
steps.description: Finish up by using a soft cloth to remove the water. Make sure no water is left or else it can damage the backsplash.

steps.headline: Blot stains immediately.
steps.description: Use paper towels to blot grease and remove food spatter. Removing stains as quickly as possible prevents them from setting. Acidic food such as tomato sauce or lemon juice can damage metal over time, so don’t let those stains linger.

steps.headline: Spray glass cleaner to remove fingerprints.
steps.description: Pick a non-chloride glass cleaner or all-surface cleaner such as Windex. Use it between washings to remove minor stains like fingerprints. Spray the cleaner across the surface of the metal. Wipe the fingerprints off with a cloth, then wipe up excess cleaner or allow it to air dry.

steps.headline: Buff the metal with olive oil.
steps.description: To give the backsplash a shine, add a tablespoon of olive oil to a soft cloth. Spend a few minutes rubbing in the oil along the grain. Leave the oil alone and it’ll protect your backsplash from stains for a few weeks. Commercial metal polish can also be used, but olive oil works well and is less expensive. Other oils, including baby oil, may also work.
